Let me tell you, every time they come up with some new gadget, some new test, it's like a challenge, a puzzle to be solved. Like a master chess player, I have to anticipate their moves, think several steps ahead.

Take, for instance, those infrared reflectography scans. They think they can see through my layers, right?  Expose my secrets?  I just use pigments that don't react the same way under infrared light. A little chemistry, a little ingenuity, and their precious scan shows them nothing but an innocent canvas.

And those X-ray fluorescence spectrometers? They think they can analyze the elemental composition of my paints, expose the differences?  I use pigments made with the same elements, just sourced differently, aged differently.  I even add a touch of "contamination" – a tiny speck of a different element – to throw them off the scent.

The art world loves its technology, but it forgets one thing: art is about emotion, about passion, about the human touch. No machine can replicate that. And as long as there's a human eye that yearns to believe, there will always be a place for a master forger like myself.
